Where do honey 
bees live?
 
The hive structure 
By the end of this lecture, you should be able to:
•
Understand the process through which wax combs are 
constructed
•
Understand the different materials that bees use to construct 
their nests
•
Explain the basic concept of “bee space” and how it governs 
nest architecture 
•
Sketch out the typical layout of a 
honey bee
 
colony, noting the 
expected locations of different kinds of comb

Humans have kept 
honey bees
 
in hives for millennia, 
yet only in recent decades have biologists begun to 
investigate how these industrious insects live in the 
wild.
The Lives of Bees
is Thomas Seeley’s captivating 
story of what scientists are learning about the behavior, 
social life, and survival strategies of 
honey bees
 
living 
outside the beekeeper’s hive―and how wild 
honey 
bees
 
may hold the key to reversing the alarming die
-
off 
of the planet’s managed 
honey bee
 
populations.
Seeley, a world authority on 
honey bees
, sheds light on 
why wild 
honey bees
 
are still thriving while those living 
in managed colonies are in crisis. Drawing on the latest 
science as well as insights from his own pioneering 
fieldwork, he describes in extraordinary detail how 
honey bees
 
live in nature and shows how this differs 
significantly from their lives under the management of 
beekeepers. Seeley presents an entirely new approach 
to beekeeping―Darwinian Beekeeping―which enables 
honey bees
 
to use the toolkit of survival skills their 
species has acquired over the past thirty million years, 
and to evolve solutions to the new challenges they face 
today. He shows beekeepers how to use the principles 
of natural selection to guide their practices, and he 
offers a new vision of how beekeeping can better align 
with the natural habits of 
honey bees
.

Part 1. What is the basic material used 
by 
honey bees
 
to build their nest?

Wax scales secreted as a 
liquid by middle aged bees, 
from their 8 wax 
glands

Beeswax quickly becomes soft and pliable at 
around 35 to 40 
°
C (when bees heat it), but it 
has a melting point of 64.5 
°
C (so a hot 
summer day will not melt the combs!) 
Beeswax has remarkable properties

6 to 8 pounds of honey
1 pound of wax
It takes 
honey bee
 
workers a lot of energy to fabricate this 
material
Size of a 
1 pound
 
block of beeswax: 
6.25" x 3.75" x 1.25"
.
Hundreds of
worker bees
were involved
in making the 
beeswax
 
of this block

combs?

Individual instinct shaped by evolution produces these

Part 3. where do 
honey bees
 
build 
their nests in the wild?

All tree hollows...

created equal
Nests are elevated and fortified!

What is a prime real estate for 
feral honey bees?
•
Sheltered, darkened enclosure
•
Entrance height:  
5m > 1m
•
Entrance area:  
15 sq cm > 75 sq cm
•
Entrance direction:  
South > North
•
Entrance position:  
Bottom > Top
•
Cavity volume: 
40L > 10L 
•
Old combs present > Empty
•
Note: Preference above assessed experimentally 
on Northeastern bees (
Ligustica
 
subspecies) 
Note: they will move into walls,
under roofs, in chimneys (etc.) if 
those nooks have the right qualities!
